intro: Leptolepidium subvillosum var. dilatatum, commonly known as the hairy leafed wintergreen, is a herbaceous plant native to the temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important plants such as mustard and cabbage. The plant is characterized by its small, elongated leaves that are often covered in fine, silky hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Its flowers are typically small and yellow, arranged in clusters, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits. This variety is adapted to grow in moist, shaded environments, often found in woodland areas and along stream banks.
